Trial_Design.evidence: A multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial was conducted.

Participants.evidence: Participants were hospitalized patients at risk of AKI, with eligibility criteria including age over 18 and no pre-existing chronic kidney disease.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received biomarker-guided management, while the control group received standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of novel biomarkers in the early diagnosis and prognosis of acute kidney injury (AKI).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of AKI within 48 hours, assessed by serum creatinine levels.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomized, with 100 in each group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in AKI incidence (mean difference = 5.2%, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with mild gastrointestinal side effects.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
